definitions.definition: The language of a people or a national language.
definitions.example: A vernacular of the United States is English.

definitions.definition: Everyday speech or dialect, including colloquialisms, as opposed to standard, literary, liturgical, or scientific idiom.
definitions.example: Street vernacular can be quite different from what is heard elsewhere.

definitions.definition: Language unique to a particular group of people; jargon, argot.
definitions.example: For those of a certain age, hiphop vernacular might just as well be a foreign language.

definitions.definition: A language lacking standardization or a written form.
Indigenous spoken language, as distinct from a literary or liturgical language such as Ecclesiastical Latin.
definitions.example: Vatican II allowed the celebration of the mass in the vernacular.

definitions.definition: Of or pertaining to everyday language, as opposed to standard, literary, liturgical, or scientific idiom.
Belonging to the country of one's birth; one's own by birth or nature; native; indigenous.
Of or related to local building materials and styles; not imported.
Connected to a collective memory; not imported.
